messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Federated Combinatorial Multi-Agent Multi-Armed Bandits

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper introduces a federated learning framework tailored for online combinatorial optimization with bandit feedback. In this setting, agents select subsets of arms, observe noisy rewards for these subsets without accessing individual arm information, and can cooperate and share information at specific intervals. Our framework transforms any offline resilient single-agent (α−ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ(\alpha-\epsilon)-approximation algorithm—having a complexity of 𝒪~​(ψϵβ)~𝒪𝜓superscriptitalic-ϵ𝛽\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\psi}{\epsilon^{\beta}}\right), where the logarithm is omitted, for some function ψ𝜓\psi and constant β𝛽\beta—into an online multi-agent algorithm with m𝑚m communicating agents and an α𝛼\alpha-regret of no more than 𝒪~​(m−13+β​ψ13+β​T2+β3+β)~𝒪superscript𝑚13𝛽superscript𝜓13𝛽superscript𝑇2𝛽3𝛽\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(m^{-\frac{1}{3+\beta}}\psi^{\frac{1}{3+\beta}}T^{\frac{2+\beta}{3+\beta}}\right). Our approach not only eliminates the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon approximation error but also ensures sublinear growth with respect to the time horizon T𝑇T and demonstrates a linear speedup with an increasing number of communicating agents. Additionally, the algorithm is notably communication-efficient, requiring only a sublinear number of communication rounds, quantified as 𝒪~​(ψ​Tββ+1)~𝒪𝜓superscript𝑇𝛽𝛽1\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\psi T^{\frac{\beta}{\beta+1}}\right). Furthermore, the framework has been successfully applied to online stochastic submodular maximization using various offline algorithms, yielding the first results for both single-agent and multi-agent settings and recovering specialized single-agent theoretical guarantees. We empirically validate our approach to a stochastic data summarization problem, illustrating the effectiveness of the proposed framework, even in single-agent scenarios.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Multi-agent multi-armed bandits with limited communication",
        "Finite-time analysis of the multiarmed bandit problem",
        "Diverse client selection for federated learning via submodular maximization",
        "The power of randomization: Distributed submodular maximization on massive datasets",
        "What doubling tricks can and can’t do for multi-armed bandits",
        "A tight linear time (1/2)-approximation for unconstrained submodular maximization",
        "Comparing apples and oranges: Query trade-off in submodular maximization",
        "The gossiping insert-eliminate algorithm for multi-agent bandits",
        "Contextual combinatorial multi-armed bandits with volatile arms and submodular reward",
        "Submodular functions, matroids, and certain polyhedra",
        "Fednew: A communication-efficient and privacy-preserving newton-type method for federated learning",
        "A threshold of ln n for approximating set cover",
        "Maximizing non-monotone submodular functions",
        "Randomized greedy learning for non-monotone stochastic submodular maximization under full-bandit feedback",
        "FilFL: Client filtering for optimized client participation in federated learning",
        "Combinatorial stochastic-greedy bandit",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming",
        "A simple and provably efficient algorithm for asynchronous federated contextual linear bandits",
        "Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables",
        "From federated to fog learning: Distributed machine learning over heterogeneous wireless networks",
        "A combinatorial strongly polynomial algorithm for minimizing submodular functions",
        "The budgeted maximum coverage problem",
        "Federated learning: Strategies for improving communication efficiency",
        "Combinatorial optimization, volume 1",
        "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images",
        "Bandit algorithms",
        "Asynchronous upper confidence bound algorithms for federated linear bandits",
        "Learning kernelized contextual bandits in a distributed and asynchronous environment",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "A class of submodular functions for document summarization",
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Distributed submodular maximization: Identifying representative elements in massive data",
        "Lazier than lazy greedy",
        "Coresets for data-efficient training of machine learning models",
        "Best algorithms for approximating the maximum of a submodular set function",
        "An analysis of approximations for maximizing submodular set functions—i",
        "Online learning via offline greedy algorithms: Applications in market design and optimization",
        "An explore-then-commit algorithm for submodular maximization under full-bandit feedback",
        "A framework for adapting offline algorithms to solve combinatorial multi-armed bandit problems with bandit feedback",
        "Gradient coreset for federated learning",
        "Introduction to multi-armed bandits",
        "A note on maximizing a submodular set function subject to a knapsack constraint",
        "Minimax optimal submodular optimization with bandit feedback",
        "Submodular bandit problem under multiple constraints",
        "Optimal algorithms for multiplayer multi-armed bandits",
        "Fashion-mnist: a novel image dataset for benchmarking machine learning algorithms",
        "“bring your own greedy”+ max: Near-optimal 1/2-approximations for submodular knapsack"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Federated Combinatorial Multi-Agent Multi-Armed Bandits, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
